content.description: Climb the face just left of the arete.  This is on the face that is north/nw facing.

sit down start to the left, throw for the large right-leaning ledge, and then continue straight up the crack that splits the center of the face.  Hint on the start:  look for the flake deep underneath the rock to push off of with your left foot.

This is new as of November 17, 2021. The boulder decided to fall apart randomly... no snow, rain, or any other weather happened when this went. Sit start as low as you can with 2 jugs if you span your arms super wide. Work up the face and arete up and left to top out.

Be careful, it broke once unprovoked... it could break again at any time.
content.location: It is on the right hand side of the "new" boulder, working up and left along the arete.

content.description: Climb starting low through several jugs to the arete proper.  Keeping one's body and feet on the right face as long as possible makes the problem more interesting.
content.protection: Pad and spotter nice but not necessary.

content.description: An eliminate. Climb left of the crack (labeled one in the picture) and right of the left arete using face holds (edges of the downward and sideward type). To finish either 1) make a long left reach to the upper part of the left arete or 2) reach from the last face holds to the last part of the crack.  Personally I like the second option, requires more thought and footwork.
content.protection: Pad and spotter nice but not necessary.

content.description:
This is basically a sit start of

Left Arete

, but it wasn't on here, so I'm adding it as it was a lot of fun.

Start matched on a big flake undercling inside the cave on the left. Work around the flake, and go out the arete. Work your way up and around onto the face. Finish straight up or traverse right to add a few more easy moves.

This had obviously been done before. A comment on Left Arete thought it went at V3, and I would agree with that.
content.location: In the 'cave' on the left of the boulder, take a look underneath, and you'll see the big flake undercling.
